name: electricity production, hard coal | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9480/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity in an average hard coal power plant in US - Hawaiian Islands Coordinating Council in 2012. "Hard coal" includes anthracite, coking coal and other bituminous coal according to the definition of the IEA electricity information 2014. (IEA. 2014. Electricity Information 2014. ISBN 978-92-64-21692-1. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR).);All exchanges in this dataset except for emissions of SO2, NOx and particles are production-weighted averages of the figures in the datasets in ecoinvent version two, which are valid for the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US. The exception values are production-weighted averages of version 2 countries and the new countries in version 3 (AU, CA, CL, ID, IN, KR, MX, MY, PE, RU, TH, TR, TW, TZ, UA, ZA);Comments on the inventory data of emissions: ;- For the assessment of main characteristics (sulphur and ash content of coal, efficiency of the plant) and CO2 a bottom-up approach has been used. It consists in the collection of information about single plants.;- The size distribution of particle emissions has been derived from German data. ; - Halogene emissions have been estimated on the basis of the content of the species in the country-specific coal input mix, assuming average retention rates. ;- For CO and particle emissions average values for the former UCTE are included (Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity).   ; - The country specific emission depend on the share of DeNOx. ; - Emissions of trace elements were calculated by means of a formula (CORINAIR) using the ash content in the country-specific coal input mix and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants, taking into account the share of DeSOx installed. ; - Emission of uranium and thorium radioactive isotopes were assumed proportional to the corresponding element emitted with particles; the other non-gaseous radioactive isotopes of the uranium and thorium decay chain were assumed proportional to the emitted U-238 or Th-232.  ;- The emission of gaseous radon and K-40 are taken from the literature.;Itten R., Frischknecht R., Stucki, M. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.;European Environment Agency (1991) CORINAIR Inventory; VOC"s Default Emission Factors

From the constructed hard coal power plant ready to produce electricity. 
From reception of hard coal and operating materials at power plant gate.

This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

This dataset includes: 
 - all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants. 
 - Use of fuel oil for startup
 - Particle removal (dedusting of the flue gas)

  - Desulfurisation and denitrification. These processes are described in separate modules; it can be decided by changing the values of NOx and SOx retained whether and how much DeNOx and DeSOx are installed. 
 - Cooling: It is assumed that all plants use wet cooling with a cooling tower. No cooling tower is included in this dataset (will be implemented in future versions)
 - Loss of feed water 


This dataset doesn"t include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets
 - transformation of the electricity produced
 - The disposal of non-recycled ashes is modelled separately.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: POWER PLANT:;Hard coal power plant input is a market mix of 100MWe power plants (representing all power plants with a capacity <250MWe and 7% of installed capacity) and 500MWe power plants (representing all power plants with a capacity >250MWe and 93% of installed capacity). Please note that in contrast to ecoinvent v2, the two power plant types do not exist anymore as single datasets. Along with (Röder et al. 2004), lifetime of these power plants is assumed to be 150’000 full load hours. Whereas European hard coal power plants are assumed to be operated in mid-load mode with 4000 full load hours per year (corresponding to a lifetime of 37.5 years) (Röder et al. 2004), a capacity factor (average US) of 66% is documented (eGRID 2006), corresponding to about 5800 full load hours per year, or a lifetime of about 26 years.;0; - Share of installed capacity with desulfurisation 2% (rough estimation based on sulfur mass balance; - Average efficiency of desulfurisation installations: 92% (rough estimation based on Dones et al. 27; - Share of installed capacity with denitrification (primary and/or secondary installations): 73% (figure based on IEA 212 ); - Average efficiency of denitrification installations: 8% (estimation based on Dones et al. 27, p.128. Valid for selective catalytic reaction systems); - Share of installed capacity with particle filters: 98% (figure based on IEA 212 ); - Average efficiency of particle filters: 98% (figure based on IEA 212 );- IEA 2012. Coal Power Database. International Energy Agency Clean Coal Centre, London ; - IEA/OECD. 2010. Electricity Information 2010. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR). Part IV. Detailed OECD Electricity And Heat Data.; - Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Data from 1993 have been updated for the years 2000 (v1.0), and 2004-2005 (v2.0). Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly. 

Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US.

The original data were valid for the burning of 1MJ of hard coal. In this dataset, the values are scaled to the net output of 1kWh of electricity, based on the electrical efficiency.

flow.name: electricity, high voltage
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal.

US average, based on (NREL 2006).

US National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2006) U.S. Life-Cycle Inventory (LCI) Database, <http://www.nrel.gov/lci/about.html>, last updated in the coal chain as of October 2006, according to http://www.nrel.gov/lci/database/pdf/USLCIDB_ChangeLog.pdf.

flow.name: Dioxins, measured as 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal. 

Average US emissions of radionuclides are based on (USEPA 1998, pg. 9-6). Reported radionuclide species without corresponding elementary flow in ecoinvent are categorized as "Actinides, radioactive, unspecified".


U. S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) (1998) The Study of Hazardous Air Pollutant Emissions from Electric Utility Steam Generating Units - Final Report to Congress. Volumes 1 and 2. EPA-453/R-98-004a and EPA-413/R-98-004b.-98-004b

flow.name: Radon-222
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Amount of CO2 emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal.

Region specific value, based on (NREL 2006). See ecoinvent report "Kohle", chapter 16, Tab. 16.10ff (Röder et al. 2007)

US National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2006) U.S. Life-Cycle Inventory (LCI) Database, <http://www.nrel.gov/lci/about.html>, last updated in the coal chain as of October 2006, according to http://www.nrel.gov/lci/database/pdf/USLCIDB_ChangeLog.pdf.

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Data from eGrid 2010. This value is given for "coal output emissions" in general in the year 2010 and is applied to both hard coal and lignite datasets. 
eGrid. The Emissions & Generation Resource Integrated Database. Year 2010 eGRID 9th edition Version 1.0 . United States Environmental Protection Agency.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Size distribution of particle emissions as well as an additional generic emissions factor of 5 kg/TJin of PM >10µm due to coal handling at the power plant site are considered along (Röder et al. 2004).

As Röder et al. 2007 do not model data for the regions ASCC and HICC, the data for these two regions are copied from WECC, US only (for ASCC) and SPP (for HICC).

US National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2006) U.S. Life-Cycle Inventory (LCI) Database, <http://www.nrel.gov/lci/about.html>, last updated in the coal chain as of October 2006, according to http://www.nrel.gov/lci/database/pdf/USLCIDB_ChangeLog.pdf.

flow.name: Acenaphthene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Size distribution of particle emissions as well as an additional generic emissions factor of 5 kg/TJin of PM >10µm due to coal handling at the power plant site are considered along (Röder et al. 2004).

As Röder et al. 2007 do not model data for the regions ASCC and HICC, the data for these two regions are copied from WECC, US only (for ASCC) and SPP (for HICC).

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 2.5 um and < 10um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Data from eGrid 2010. This value is given for "coal output emissions" in general in the year 2010 and is applied to both hard coal and lignite datasets. 
eGrid. The Emissions & Generation Resource Integrated Database. Year 2010 eGRID 9th edition Version 1.0 . United States Environmental Protection Agency.

flow.name: Nitrogen oxides
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Amounts of retained NOx and SO2 had to be modeled as US averages, since no region-specific data on NOx and SOx retention were available. According to (NREL 2006), 33% of US coal power plant capacity is equipped with Flue Gas Desulphurization (FGD) units and these FGD units show an average removal efficiency of 85%. Emissions of SO2 and NOx from US average coal power plants without employment of FGD are documented in (NREL 2006 after AP-42 1998). The difference between these uncontrolled US averages and the region-specific actual emissions has served as an approximation for region-specific amounts of retained NOx and SO2.

As Röder et al. 2007 do not model data for the regions ASCC and HICC, the data for these two regions are copied from WECC, US only (for ASCC) and SPP (for HICC).

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Light fuel oil use per 1MJ of hard coal burned, use for start-up of the power plant after shut down. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and ight fuel oil use values of 14 countries 
(AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US) (Röder et al. 2007) 
Country values are typical values for hard coal plants. 

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 
Hard coal ash can either be used as secondary product ("recycled"), or be disposed of. According to (NREL 2006), the rate of ash production is 0.0915 kg ash per kg burned coal (includes fly ash, bottom ash, and boiler slag). Thereof, 30% is further used; the rest must be disposed of (NREL 2006).
US National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2006) U.S. Life-Cycle Inventory (LCI) Database, <http://www.nrel.gov/lci/about.html>, last updated in the coal chain as of October 2006, according to http://www.nrel.gov/lci/database/pdf/USLCIDB_ChangeLog.pdf.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. At the moment, the hard coal power plant input consists of a market mix of a 100MWe power plant and a 500MWe power plant
. 
For this calculation, 4000 load hours per year are assumed. It is assumed that a total of 150"000h is reached during the lifetime. A capacity of 500MW is taken for the calculation.

flow.name: Chloroform
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The quantification of coal input depends on the energy content of the coal burned. This energy content differs for single hard coal qualities from different production regions from 19.4 MJ/kg to 31.5 MJ/kg (MIT 2007). For the US NERC regions, the supply is modeled with three production regions with hard coal of different quality and thus energy content. 

Appalachian coal (in terms of lower heating value = 27.5 MJ/kg) is assumed to be used in the following NERC regions: FRCC, NPCC, and RFC. Western coal (LHV = 20.2 MJ/kg) is assumed to be used in the regions ERCOT, MRO, and WECC. Coal from the Interior (LHV = 24.5 MJ/kg) is assumed to be used in the region SPP; and the SERC region is assumed to be supplied by mix of different qualities, i.e. US average hard coal mix as first approximation (LHV = 24.0 MJ/kg). This modelling appears to be consistent with the coal production per region (Appalachian, West, Interior) (MIT 2007) and the consumption per NERC region in 2004 (eGRID 2006), because the total amounts of coal from the three regions for power plant supply are below the total coal production in these mining regions.

MIT 2007: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2007) The Future of Coal. Options for a carbon constrained world. ISBN 978-0-615-14092-6. MIT, Cambridge, US, <http://web.mit.edu/coal/>.

eGRID 2006: Emissions & Generation Resource Integrated Database (2006) Inventory of US electric power system, excel-file "eGRID2006yr04plant121506.xls" (15.12.2006), <http://www.epa.gov/cleanenergy/egrid/index.htm>.

flow.name: Benzo(a)pyrene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Literature value/calculated value. Cooling water, decarbonised, for the cooling water circuit lost when producing 1kWh of electricity from hard coal, based on the value for burning 1MJ of hard coal. Röder et al. 2007, Tab. 9.65 and Tab. 9.66, p. 160f. These tables give an amount of 0.15 kg/MJ burned, which is valid for the assumption of 75% wet cooling and 25% run-through cooling. However, this revised dataset assumes 100% wet cooling.

US National Renewable Energy Laboratory (2006) U.S. Life-Cycle Inventory (LCI) Database, <http://www.nrel.gov/lci/about.html>, last updated in the coal chain as of October 2006, according to http://www.nrel.gov/lci/database/pdf/USLCIDB_ChangeLog.pdf.

flow.name: Hydrocarbons, aliphatic, alkanes, unspecified
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density
